title: John Carlson takes NHL points lead, continues making history with streak
text:
When a Washington Capitals player leads the NHL in points, it’s understandable that casual fans would assume that player is Alex Ovechkin, or even someone like Nicklas Backstrom, who plays on the top forward line and is involved in assisting plenty of goals.

But on Monday morning, John Carlson was the man atop the league leaderboard. Yes, that John Carlson. The defenseman.

Carlson extended his point streak to seven games with an assist in Washington’s 5-3 win over Chicago on Sunday night, bringing his season total to 18 points (three goals, 15 assists) in 10 games.

With an assist on an Ovechkin goal Sunday, Carlson broke a tie at 17 points with Edmonton Oilers center Connor McDavid — one of the NHL’s top young superstars — for sole possession of the league lead. His mark of 15 assists also leads the league, three more than second-place McDavid has.

While the sport undoubtedly has trended toward wanting more skilled blueliners, a player like Carlson being a points leader is unheard of. Only two other defensemen in league history have tallied 18 or more points in their teams’ first 10 games of a season — and they’re Hall of Famers Bobby Orr and Paul Coffey. It hasn’t happened since 1988.

“For a defenseman, I think there’s so much luck involved,” Carlson said before Friday’s game, a win over the Rangers in which he racked up three assists. “I think I’m making good plays, don’t get me wrong. I’m not just dumping the puck in, although I did have one or two of those as well. Chances happen, chances get created and sometimes they go in and sometimes they don’t. They seem to be going in right now which is nice.

“I’ll just keep working it the same way. It’s about the process more than what happens on the other side of it.”
